source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: Desirable mechanical properties are obtained by quenching from a temperature high in the (α + β)-phase region (generally 850 to 880 C) and stabilizing the structure by aging in the α-phase region (500 to 575 C).
process_step: quenching from 850-880 C, aging at 500-575 C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: Cold work between quenching and aging enhances some properties, notably corrosion resistance.
process_step: cold work between quenching and aging

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: Using specimens annealed at 650 to 700 C for 30 min before testing
process_step: annealing at 650-700 C for 30 min

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: increasing the niobium concentration improved mechanical properties but decreased the corrosion resistance

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: They recommended the 1 percent niobium alloy for use in 350 C water

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: specimens which had been quenched from the β-phase and annealed at 500 C for 24 h
process_step: quenching from β-phase, annealing at 500 C for 24 h

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: They recommended the addition of 0.2 to 1 percent Nb for corrosion resistance to aqueous environments but found poor oxidation resistance in air

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: material cooled from the β phase had poor corrosion resistance
process_step: cooling from β phase

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: corrosion resistance of welds could be improved by post-weld annealing for 8 h at 1100 F (593 C)
process_step: post-weld annealing at 593 C for 8 h

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: poor oxidation resistance of welds in 2.5Nb zirconium could be ameliorated by post-weld annealing at 700 C
process_step: post-weld annealing at 700 C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: prolonged overheating at 350 C and even 400 C did not impair the corrosion resistance

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: Boulton [5], in autoclave tests on cold-rolled 2.5Nb zirconium, confirmed the earlier observations and emphasized the comparatively low hydrogen pick-up
process_step: cold rolling

evidence_span: oxidation of the 2.5Nb alloy less affected by neutron radiation in steam at 400 C than that of Zircaloy-2

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: β-quenched and aged material had reasonable oxidation resistance to aqueous environments both out-reactor and in pressurized water with low fast-neutron flux
process_step: β-quenching and aging

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: low hydrogen pick-up on aqueous oxidation and poor resistance to oxidation in air were noted

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: corrosion tests on 2.5Nb zirconium in steam and air at temperatures from 300 to 600 C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: Most tests were on material quenched from 900 C (that is, close to the (α + β)/β transus temperature) and aged for various times and temperatures

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: beneficial effect on oxidation resistance of prolonged aging in the α-region (below approximately 600 C)
process_step: prolonged aging in α-region

evidence_span: The effects of aging temperature, aging time, and cold work between quenching and aging on the out-reactor corrosion resistance of $2 . 5 \mathsf { N b }$ zirconium have been systematically studied

evidence_span: Figure 1 illustrates how the poor corrosion resistance of 2.5Nb zirconium in $3 1 6 \mathrm { { C } }$ water may be improved by cold work and aging
